awd_titl_txt: Microscopic Properties of Hot and Dense QCD Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
A few micro-seconds into the cooling process of the early Universe, an extremely hot plasma of elementary particles (quarks and gluons) condensed into bound states called hadrons, the building blocks of the visible matter in the Universe. The condensation of the quark-gluon  plasma (QGP) confined the quarks and gluons into hadrons and generated about 98% of the visible mass. The discovery of the mechanisms of quark confinement and hadron mass generation  are central goals of fundamental research in particle and nuclear physics. Experimentally, small droplets of QGP, at record temperatures exceeding 2 trillion Kelvin, can be re-created in the laboratory by colliding atomic nuclei at high energies, at the Relativistic Heavy-Ion Collider and the Large Hadron Collider. However, it is very challenging to infer the properties of the QGP and its hadronization from the measured particle spectra. The PI, together with his graduate students and collaborators, will develop theoretical methods and apply them to unravel fundamental properties of the QGP from experimental data. His research and educational activities also encompass undergraduate research and outreach to high-school students within the Saturday Morning Physics program at Texas A&M. 

The heavy charm and bottom quarks, as well as electromagnetic (EM) radiation, are particularly valuable probes of the QGP. The PI will use state-of-the-art quantum many-body theory of the strong nuclear force to analyze the diffusion of heavy quarks (Brownian motion) and their subsequent hadronization. A systematic analysis of the experimental spectra of baryons (3-quark states) and mesons (quark-antiquark states) containing heavy quarks will unravel mechanisms of hadronization and provide unprecedented precision in the extraction of the heavy-quark diffusion coefficient, a key quantity to characterize the interaction strength in the QGP. The PI will further use EM radiation, which can penetrate the QGP formed in heavy-ion collisions, to analyze the mechanism of mass generation. He will investigate the spectral modifications of baryons near the hadronization transition and extract the electric conductivity, another fundamental transport parameter of the medium.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The mass of the matter around us was most likely generated in the very early universe, about 10 micro-seconds after the Big Bang. During this time an extremely hot plasma of the elementary particles called quarks and gluons (at temperatures in excess of 1 trillion degrees) converted into the nucleons (and other "hadrons") which form the basic building blocks of atoms. It is truly fascinating that modern-day experiments can recreate the quark-gluon plasma in the laboratory, by colliding atomic nuclei at the highest available energies. However, the quark-gluon plasma expands very rapidly and is very short-lived, so that its properties have to be inferred from the spectra of thousands of particles observed the large detectors. 

The PI and his research group have continued their theoretical studies using the diffusion of heavy charm and bottom quarks as probes of the quark-gluon plasma and its conversion into hadrons. Their most recent transport model applications to charm-hadron spectra measured at the Relativistic Heavy-Ion Collider (RHIC, at Brookhaven National Lab) and the Large Hadron Collider (LHC, at CERN in Geneva, Switzerland) resulted in a good agreement with the experimental data. This enabled a much improved extraction of the charm-quark diffusion coefficient, which turns out be be very close to a conjectured lower bound set by the laws of quantum mechanics. It also corroborates and quantifies the notion of the quark-gluon plasma as the "most perfect liquid" ever made. Moreover, the theoretical predictions encompassed a variety of charm hadrons (including those that are made of charm and anti-charm quarks) which provides direct connections between the plasma's extraordinary transport properties and the confining force that binds charm quarks into charm hadrons.

The PI has continued to build an inter/nationally visible and integrated research and education program at Texas A&M University. He has supervised research projects of four graduate and five undergraduate students. Together with international collaborators, these projects led to about 20 peer-reviewed publications in high-quality scientific journals and enabled the completion of two PhD theses and one undergraduate research scholar thesis. The PI further pursued the Saturday Morning Physics program for high-school students in South-East Texas, which he had originally introduced at Texas A&M in 2006. This program has been run with 7 events in the spring '20 and '22 semesters  (with a pandemic-related interruption in '21), attracting a total of ca. 100-150 high-school students of a diverse background each year.
